segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Alright, off we go. So, hello all. My name is Mariusz and I'm a Red Teamer back in ING.
We are doing this like global Red Team engagements and therefore we have collected a bunch of
tricks that were useful during our endeavors and as well as since I'm especially inclined
towards the malware because I used to analyze and dissect malware samples as well as write
my own. Therefore, I am more interested in devising malware stuff so I would like to
share with you a little bit of tricks and tactics that we could use malware wise towards
increasing our chances during the Red Team operations that we'll be having. So, what
we'll be sharing today is a few tricks about the phishing as well as how can we approach
the initial access stage in the more highly secure environments as well as a little
more into the evasion ideas. Because, as we might imagine, the evasion is really important
in order to survive the multiple stages of detection and sensing dodgy stuff. Therefore,
we might want to cover some of the more recent ideas how to combat them. And, as a disclaimer,
of course, there are no fancy new tactics in this talk. We've got a bunch of stuff that we
use and keep privately low-profile so that we can operate still within our networks. But,
among the things that I can show to you today, we'll be covering a few ideas that are already
quite known but yet can be still weaponized and used during the engagement. So, one of the tricks
that we really like abusing is to use the legitimate third-party services, such as,
for instance, LinkedIn, and abuse them to smuggle the URLs so that the employees who are not that
sensitive about conversating with the mind-like experts from all around the world are more inclined
into opening, actually, this kind of stuff. So, smuggling the malicious payloads within the
attachments is no more a viable approach towards targeting companies because the email scanning
systems are so good at detecting dodgy stuff within the attachments. Therefore, we would
consider to just sticking away from the attachments-based malware and sticking more
into the URLs. And URLs have this little bit of a problem for the security scanning and the proxies
and systems because it's hard to tell the intention of the landing page that the user is about to hit.
So, there's very hard logic to be implemented towards sensing whether the URL attached to the
email is going to be dodgy or not. And among the other tricks that we might chain altogether
within the email or the conversation that we'll be trying to develop are the things like the
right-to-left-over-right trick, which still works quite nice during the most recent times,
even though that was designed or devised 10 or 20 years ago. So, it still keeps on giving.
And also, we consider that these little bit of not so developed phishing ideas for just firing
a single email and forgetting about it and just waiting for the user to get infected are no more
so much successful anymore because users are not so much inclined into clicking on the very
first email that they have received from this particular sender. In order to better understand
what we are dealing with while we are delivering the email message, we came to the effort to just
actually send hundreds of emails towards the Office 365 email scanning system, the Microsoft
Defender for Office 365, and we've been trying to conclude what were the SMTP headers getting back
to us when we're trying to analyse and examine the results during our internal analysis efforts. And
we came to the observation that there were more than 20 SMTP threat rules and rule numbers that
we could actually, with a great deal of certainty, establish that the rules are getting back to these
particular observations related to the emails. So, for instance, having the sole existence of the
A URL within the mail is going to trigger back on a single anti-spam or threat rule,
so we could just imagine, but there are a bunch of others that will be hitting back on our emails
that we could be aware of, so I think that this is a valuable idea to try to learn how our mails
are getting scanned and what engrams are being extracted out from our emails. And then, before
we actually deliver something, we could be applying this idea of linting our phishing emails before we
actually fire them away. And by the linting, we mean to have a couple of safe checks implemented
within our scriptings. So, for instance, stuff like how many URL parameters are there in the
URL that we are about to attach into the email message. This is the concept that still matters,
because we have observed, just let me get back to the previous slide, we have observed by going
through all of these rules that there were some rules that were like more rules being provided
back to us when we provided the URL containing multiple get parameters, whereas while we kept
it short, lean, and mean, quite concise URL, it will get back with less amount of anti-spam rules
in SMTP headers. Therefore, we concluded that we would be better off with keeping our URLs nice
and tidy. And among the other tricks that we found is that there has to be HTML smuggling
involved when we're targeting Office 365 environments, because just simply pointing
towards the file would obviously get that file being fetched by the automated sandboxing mechanism,
and therefore it might get detonated and, of course, burned before we even reach out to the
very first employee that we try to target. So, well, stating the obvious, we cannot have this
kind of bad smells within our URLs, so just like pointing to, directly pointing to the extension,
because obviously the automated, and especially during the machine learning times, automated
models are going to be very sensitive about it, therefore we are applying this idea of linting
our phishing mails before we actually fire them away, so that we won't be living this kind of
smelly traces. And among the others, what we found is that, for instance, even such an idea
of embedding images and encoded within the base 64 blobs within the HTML is going to impact the
number of anti-spam rules being matched on our email, so we found that it's so much easier and
so much safer to just point to the remotely hosted images while still risking the notion that the
employee might not enable fetching remote resources. We are okay with that, as well as
trying to maybe attach them to the email, just as we are attaching the images within the signature.
So, the base 64 is a not-so-stable approach to go about designing HTMLs, and it might be a little
bit hard to explain, but what we found during our trials and errors was that this convoluted
approach of free next-hop servers targeting the Office 365 environments worked the best for us.
So, the first one will be having this go phish on the EC2 instance, then there is going to be
a vanilla, empty EC2 redirector that just pushes on behalf of SoCat all the emails targeting the
557 TCP port, and then redirecting them away to the SMTP, which is a high-reputational,
well-trusted mail delivery system. And therefore, Office 365 will just send back all the way to the
very beginning on the received service examination. So, it will sense that, okay,
this is the SMTP, and this is the Gmail that provided me that email, and Gmail is going to
do the same about our vanilla EC2 instance, and it's not going to send anything dodgy about it,
because the IP points back to the AWS and states, therefore, this might be a well-trusted IP pool,
so Gmail may be not so picky about it, and therefore, we can deliver the emails to the
Office 365. At least, this is what we are speculating how this might work, because obviously,
it's like a black box, therefore, we cannot be sure. Also, what we observed is that after
delivering this fourth of five emails, Defender is going to cool down on us, but then after waiting
a few hours, we'll be able to bring back on the same domain that we used to deliver these first
emails. Now, with regards to the initial access, there are a few approaches that still work,
and of course, this is very, very highly environment, as well as company-independent,
therefore, some of the tricks might work for your environment, whereas they won't work for ours,
so the gift that keeps on giving is the idea to fish to persist instead of fishing to access,
and there was this very nicely put up the article coming from MatHand from Spector Ops,
which is exactly described what we were thinking about for the past months, but we couldn't just
put up in this elegant words, wording as he did, so for instance, it's so much better,
it's so much more reliable to just drop the DLL into a very specific sweet spot and have that DLL
follow the proxying or the side-loading idea, so for instance, we could very easily weaponize
the side-loading against Teams, where we can just easily find that Teams is trying to load up the
version DLL coming out from its Microsoft Teams directory within the local app data, therefore,
we can easily craft our own dodgy DLL and just persist from inside of the VBScript or the VBA,
just easily while still the chaining the file right and exact steps. Yeah, so I wouldn't be
so inclined into using the typical Windows script host kind of file vectors, things like HDAs,
JScripts and VBScripts used to work for many years, but now, when we have the era of very
aggressively configured EDRs or EPP products, as well as proxies, that even tries to pull the,
to extract the files and pass them to the automated detonation environments,
so that we can just briefly mention about the Zscaler, who is having this like Apex sandbox
bundle within it, so some of the proxy systems are very aggressive towards the files, therefore,
using that kind of all the vectors might not be reliable for our highly scrutinized environments.
So, for instance, oh, well, obviously, transmitting the executable ones to just MSC,
MSI files installation and installations systems, as well as executables just simply exist. Well,
however, this was convenient for a pretty long time, it's not much more and reliable as we can
already know it, and there was this very nice research coming from George and Konstantinos
back maybe a year or two years ago, and they have described this very nice and hefty ideas
for bypassing specific products, and we've been trying to, we've been heavily utilizing their
outcomes, and what we can, for instance, say here, that some of the executable files will just slip
through the product because of some unknown reasons, and this is exactly the same for the
CrowdStrike, which is known to be susceptible to having the CPL files, and the CPL file is just a
simple DLL that exposes merely a single export, and also there is this idea that we shouldn't be
reliable on having plain DLLs, having this the malicious code within the DLL main is going to
cause us a lot of problems because of the loader lock issues, therefore you might be better off
finding primitives to run your dodgy code from the exported functionality instead of DLL main,
because you'll be experiencing this undefined, unpredictable behaviors when you try to load
your shellcode from inside of the DLL main, just because of this loader lock issues, therefore
CPL is like a perfect idea to weaponize that kind of thinking about the DLLs, and also the
LNK files, the LNKs are such a decade-old threat, we cannot even think about, we cannot even imagine
why is that threat still noticed during the 2022, where Microsoft is so aggressive towards the
macros, and is so aggressive towards applying the mark of the web idea towards plenty other
file formats, why do they don't do the same thing about the LNKs, like we've been trying to come up
with observation how much common is for our employees to use to transmit LNK files, and
we've seen as it results from my talks with the blue team guys, who have been trying to do this
like threat hunting queries, that the LNKs could be quite easily blocked on the perimeter of the
customers, therefore we might be just suggesting them to block that extension right away, without
losing any business use cases. As well as HTML files, the HTML are not so anticipated as the
malware vector, and still they can be delivered even inside of the attachment, and the HTML can
easily contain the smuggling payload, therefore constituting all the rest of the infection chain,
just from inside of the simple email attachment, and what's funny about this email
attachment, is that we can apply this really old trick of just inputting this dandy Unicode byte
into the file name, so that it will mingle with how the file name is being printed,
represented back to the user, and therefore trying to fool the more tech savvy users into
thinking that they are dealing with this maybe a little bit more legitimate file, such as Fox1.
Also, the VBA malware. Well, we consider that the VBA isn't going away
any much soon, because of how much is it used by the big players, such as hedge funds
companies, and the financial sector, and the brokers. I even have my friend who is a lawyer,
and he told me that he's so used to working with VBA macros, even the lawyers, like colleague
lawyers, are using that mechanism, that functionality, because they also have their
own automated Excel spreadsheets that somebody has written years ago, that they are using inside of
their companies. Therefore, it is still a viable approach targeting lesser aware users, that the
yellow ribbon enabling them, making them enable macros, is not so scary after all, because we've
used to work with this kind of files, therefore we can go about it. And there's also a very nice
podcast with Risky Business, where the CEO of CrowdStrike shares some of his insights with
what he learned from talking with Microsoft on this pushing back on macros decision, and I highly
recommend going back and listening to that podcast, because it's very insightful. And also, we can
think of millions of ways we could actually weaponize VBA to bring us the code execution
primitive, but according to our researchers, we have this like maybe 20 of different code
patterns implemented within the VBA, and the three ones that are the most effective, that we found
the most effective, were the simple file droppers, as well as the idea of James Forshaw for having
this realization from inside of the VBA code, through the use of .NET interoperability interfaces,
and in XSL transfer mode, which applies the same logic. Also, there are some more or less
anticipated file formats, so just plain simple word, we all are aware of the remote template
trick within the words, when we can just deliver the plain simple docs file without the macros,
which will then be having this like a reference to the remotely hosted template, that template
can have arbitrary example, meaning we don't need to follow this .tm kind of naming. Therefore,
we could dechain the infection into two stages, first delivering the macro-less document, then
having the macro-enabled payload delivered back to us during the remote resources fetching,
and the same approach can be applied to the XLS by the use of mechanics called custom UI,
which was designed to provide the customers the ability to customize the ribbon within the office
applications, and also PowerPoint. PowerPoint is also not so much anticipated format, and we found
that in our community, and I found that in while working with my customers, that they haven't been
experiencing macro-enabled PowerPoints, therefore they never considered that the PowerPoint might
be the dangerous one, and also the same observation applies to lesser known and more even exotic
formats, but they don't share the same risk exposure, because the Visio or the project is not
so commonly pre-installed, there are this like additional applications, but still we need to be
aware that while targeting critical infrastructure sectors, there are these architects and engineers
who are used to work with CAD software, and CAD software typically has this backward compatibility
with the Visio diagrams, therefore devising malware for Visio will get the power plant sector
infected as well, because of the software that the engineers and architects are using there,
so we see that there are plenty more of dodgy extensions that we could be aware of,
and therefore instruct our customers to protect themselves from. And to just support what we
have already said, the VBA runtime engine is not only present within the Microsoft products,
it is very ubiquitous among the architects and engineers, especially in CAD software,
as well as other exotic ones, such as ArcMap, GIS templates, and even oscilloscopes may have
this support for VBA code, which is kind of interesting. Therefore, this increases the
threat surface that there is actually behind the VBA story. And now, a little bit of a backstory
of the containerization idea. So, I assume that we are all aware of the fact that Microsoft tried
to apply this quite a nicely sounding logic of blocking macros, whenever they have this
like paint flag that they are marked that they came from the internet, therefore these files
cannot be trusted because they come from the untrusted source, so the macro is decided,
so the office applications are deciding that, well, since that file source cannot be trusted,
therefore I am not willing to run its code, therefore I'll make the decision for the
user instead and just make him unable to even enable macros. So, since we've been trying to
find that kind of functionality applied to the Office 365, we've seen the Microsoft
representatives telling that they have this very robust protection against the mark of the web.
Well, I couldn't find the proper version of the Office 365 environment. Maybe you can just
approach me after this talk and point me to the specific installation that has this feature
enforced, but I couldn't just reproduce it. So, we didn't yet found the exactly running
and working idea for blocking MOTEVU-enabled documents. So, in practice, it means that
currently this doesn't really act as an evasion. We have the evasion before even the security
measurements was implemented, at least this is like my point of view, but it can act as the way
of showing to the customers that there are way much more extensions that should be considered
as dangerous and therefore untrusted, such as ISOs or even IMGs, which are not so popular as
the concept of ISO, and IMG is simply a synonym to the ISO. We can just simply rename the extension
and we will have the same ISO inside of it, and we will be probably aware that the files within
the container will not have the mark of the web file taint flag propagated. Therefore, even if
the container itself is considered as coming from untrusted, the file inside of that container
won't apply the same observation. And also, it was quite surprising to us that during the
actual engagement, while we were constantly observing the print screens coming from back
of our beacons, we just observed these employees that were working with these PDF files
that had like 10 and more files embedded inside of them. And this was the Eureka idea for us,
that hey, since the employees are using and do know, they are familiarized with this mechanism
of having files embedded into the PDF, we are going to weaponize that and we are going to reuse
that idea for our endeavors. And it kind of worked, so we can also store files within the PDFs and
have even them quite automatically popped in front of the user. And as you can see from the
social engineering perspective, the prompt is already having this like secure defaults and
the enabling button is already highlighted. Therefore, just simply hitting enter or just
forgetting about to read all of this boring stuff that is on the dialog is enough to get
one's infected. And now comes the beauty of HTML smuggling. So, the idea of HTML smuggling is known
for a couple of years and we all learned, I guess that at least I have learned about this idea from
the outlying guys who just share this very cool research about the notion of having malware
embedded within the HTML, which in turn contains this JavaScript. So, there is this JavaScript
automation that will unpack the file and drop it to the hard drive during the drive-by occasion.
And this is just so surprising that this idea gets our malicious files, regardless of their
extension, regardless of their contents, easily just right into the victim's hard drive,
because the proxies, as well as any other network positioned systems, have no way to differentiate
whether the HTML or JavaScript is dodgy. And even if they were trying to just hook into this
dodgy world, we could apply heavy JavaScript obfuscations. Therefore, this is not the best
idea for them to even try to sense the dodginess within the JavaScript. And the only way to protect
against it is to come up with clever and robust HIPPS rules on the downloads directory that the
customers could apply. So, for instance, running the CPL files from the downloads directory. This
is an anomaly that we could model our detections around. Therefore, we could kill it by simply
denying the system to even think about running CPLs from the downloads ones. But also, this idea
will only be effective if we anticipate, if we model the fact that our landing pages are going
to be heavily scanned by the automated sandboxes, proxies, and even the prying eyes of looting
analysts. So, we need to come up with this anti-headless timing device, even the post-delivery
and redirection, as well as we might be thinking about deploying decoy documents, so-called plausible
deniability something. And then, as you can see, as we can see all, there's like so much, so much
to protect against. Like, during my attempt to collect every extensions that I would see quite
nicely weaponized, I came up with this 70, 73 extensions list. Maybe there's much more. These
are at least the ones that I think that I will be able to weaponize. Therefore, they pose actual
risk to the customers that we are protecting. So, just simply trying to discuss with
them the possibility of blocking these extensions if there is no business case for
having them coming from the internet would be a nice mitigation strategy. Now, let's get to the
second part of this talk, the evasion in depth. So, in order to maximize our chances for the
successful breach, we need to be thinking about evasions at every step of the kill chain that
we try to simulate. So, every step of the kill chain comes with its unique challenges that we
need to combat. And all of these challenges, when we are trying to emulate them inappropriately,
will be leaving traces behind us. And therefore, we should be trying to first test our samples
within our environments, apply the threat hunting, as well as threat detection ideas
ourselves within our lab environments, so that we can be in advanced compared to our blue team
colleagues and see what our samples are leaving behind and try to address that traces and that
leftovers ourselves. So, starting with the delivery, we found that hosting our payloads
within the good reputation servers, such as clouds, are the best way to get into the company,
because, of course, this isn't that simple to just block entire windows.net domain. Therefore,
we might be abusing multiple different, for instance, Azure services to host our payloads,
and there is no clear idea what to do about it when you think about companies' large-scale
solutions to this problem. Therefore, I guess that it is beneficial to come over that threat,
to try to model it and try to see if there is anything that we could do about it. So,
for instance, I know that some customers can simply block entire Amazon AWS.net,
because they are not using AWS resources. Therefore, at least minimizing the threat
surface of that cloud. And also, Mr. Docs has this very cool project called Living of Trusted
Sites, when he tries to collect every domain, every internet service that could be reused,
repurposed for the file storage primitive. So, for instance, he just disclosed to us that we
can simply upload the file as attachments while working on the email within the Office 365 Outlook,
and that file will then be immediately uploaded to the Azure cloud and will get back to us with
this nice Outlook live.net domain URL. So, it will be quite trusted, but yet it comes with this
very short validity of ten minutes, something like that. So, it's not that useful, but there
are plenty of other ideas. Also, before we actually deliver the Office document, for instance, we
should be applying multiple evasions on the file level as well. So, for instance, VBA purging,
which works very good, even now during the 2022 year. But yet, there is this, I would call it the
backdoor. If you check out the official repository on the GitHub with the Office purge, there is this
left idea for having Yara signature being applicable on the documents purged with that tool.
Therefore, I would be advising to find another tool. There's a forked one that will get your
files a little bit more stealthier as compared to Office purging one. And the Office document
encryption is a terrifying approach to just cut down on the detection to the very zero level when
you just apply your custom password, or even the hard-coded default one, Velvet Sweatshop,
will cut it because as long as the victim provides his own password, the antiviruses and EDR stuff
are unable to sense anything out of it. And also, when it comes to what we actually can do with
the VBA, .NET 2.js is a still gift that keeps on giving, and even when it comes to Microsoft
attack surface reduction rules, there's this rule called block Office applications from injecting
into other processes, and we found that these ASR rules are ineffective against .NET 2.js, .NET
loaded and deserialized assemblies. Also, the idea that we really like is to use the XSL transform
node that we can see on the right-hand side, higher image. We are just providing the URL,
or even we can provide the entire VBS XML, and that XML, XSL rather, can contain the VBScript
or the JScript, and that one will be launched, deserialized within the memory, therefore giving
us this low footprint, quite stealthy code execution primitive from inside of the VBA.
And also, if we want to actually run something inside of the system, try to use the
dechained execution approach, so instead of running your commands inside of the child processes,
try to look for the primitives that will let you dechain the parent-child relationship. And also,
don't evade Emsi from inside of the VBA, just look for the other ways around it, like for instance,
using the more sophisticated VBA implementations. Instead of trying to patch the memory of the Emsi,
this is not the way to go. This is not a scalable way to go. And another thing is that using the
community malware, which Cobalt Strike is right now considering us, as well as the Metasploit one,
Covenant one, they are used as these benchmarks for EDRs. The EDRs need to fine-tune their own
detections towards these products, because the entire community expects that, for instance,
the EDR X0-XZ will be sensing Cobalt Strike within the memory, regardless of how well was
it hidden. Therefore, the Cobalt Strike will get us, at some point, probably detected,
so we can think about moving towards another C2 implants, such as, for instance, Mythic C2,
which is an open-source one, and it's really, really affordable to just try to work with it
and come up with our custom implant for the Mythic, and keep it in-house, just for the case.
And also, if you work with Sliver, just think about the idea that executes assembly,
which is very convenient, follows the fork-and-run approach, which is something I'm going to briefly
cover in just about seconds. This is quite a loud idea for running our .NETs. When we think
about delivering the executables, also bear in mind that there is this prevalence and reputation
analysis that our executable, regardless of how sophisticated that was, was only seen in
two devices worldwide. Therefore, it is considered as anomalous, because it's so uncommon, so it
will be detected and mitigated, contained, even before it has a chance to shine and chance to
apply all its sophisticated evasions and patches, and so on. So strive for the DLS side-loading,
hijacking, comp hijacking, wherever you want it, just don't use exists. Also, if you want to
deliver the actual executable, you can think about heavily obfuscating your stuff. So there is this
concept of obfuscators and protectors. I'm sure that we worked with UPIX and ConfuserX before.
The only idea that I wanted to kind of enhance and release to my Red Team colleagues is to apply
the entire daisy-chained load of full of the packers, so that we can have the result of one
packer being fed to the other packer, and then even further complicate the stuff, and even maybe
just apply some other stages to just signing files using the skr, crow, or the mangle one, or even
removing pair resources using pair reset, for instance, or even backdoor the files using the
backdoor one. And also, when we are talking about responsibly delivering our cyber weapons,
think about watermarking your implants. So just intentionally inject some signatures into your
implants, so then when the Blue Team will get back to you in about half of a year later, and they will
ask you, is that yours? You'll be comfortable with saying, yes, that is ours, because we extracted
this as JSON blob from inside of that executable, and we were able to apply our password that we
have documented somewhere in our systems, and therefore we can extract the metadata out of
the beacon or out of the malware ourselves. So ideas where to store, where to stuff that kind
of watermarking are very simple. Just use the P headers, maybe resources, maybe just stick up with
the additional P section, maybe even tamper with the DOS stub instead. Also, if you want to backdoor
something because you like feeling that you really need to have this informer of a shellcode, but you
still would like to leverage, to abuse the fact that there are plenty of rich resources, icons,
cursors, and so on, you could try to inject your payload into the legitimate library using quite a
few ideas for writing and executing your shellcodes. And these two tools, the backdoor one,
watermarker one, are bundled within the protect my tooling package. So if you fancy using them,
check out the GitHub repository that contains them already. And one of the ideas that I would
recommend would be to try to store your shellcode in the middle of the first code section so that
we don't introduce yet another one, as long as the shellcode is not overly long, and then try to
hijack branching instruction from the original entry point and then point it towards the shellcode
that you just injected, so that we don't even tamper with the address of entry point P header
structure. And even there is this funny thing about just applying fake code signatures onto
our implants. So for instance, here we are taking this idea and implementation and an exported
certificate from manifestation MacGyver from SpectraOps, and we are just taking his fake code
certificate, we are applying it on the Apollo, and as we can see, Apollo before signing 30
detections, after signing with fake, still stolen certificates, eight less, and it just happens that
a few products were sustainable to this kind of fooling around them. There is this also
quite a fresh idea of pumping and bloating our malware samples. I haven't played with that much
with them myself yet, but we've heard that we can just inject the plenty of words, of English words,
to the very end of the executable, so that we can try to strive towards lower effective entropy of
the entire file. So that is the idea behind file pumping. And the file bloating, if we have the
implant that will act as our persistent one, and we leave it on our hard drive, how about just
increasing in size into something ridiculous, such as maybe 50 megs, and just leave it out there,
so that maybe some AVs and EDRs will just look at this size and say that this is not something for
me. Among the strategies that we can apply is to try to, of course, time delay the execution
primitives that we have. When we, during our shellcode execution, there is this allocation,
write, and execution steps. We could apply heavy delays among these subsequent steps,
following the drip loader style of injecting stuff. It is quite effective towards the
crowdstrike even today, but just requires a little bit of love for refactoring it and playing
with the source code. And then also, we could apply some blending in to just find the
remote process, if we really want to go about remote injection, and to find about process that
Duke has already pre-loaded CLR, WinHTTP, CRUD UI, so that we will be living inside of the
quite legitimate process. But instead, I would advise against injecting it to remote processes,
because it is so complicated to do it right, without leaving many traces behind. Even the
sole idea of direct syscalls can be implemented inappropriately, therefore leaving traces and
the detection primitives. So, just try to stay in process, in line, instead of injecting. Forget
injecting anything. We don't need to inject anymore. If we stay inside, if we operate inside
of the DLL that was loaded to the team server, there is just no need for us to keep on injecting
outside of the teams, because we are already living in the legitimate process, right? So,
in order to push back on the DOM's Yara signatures, we could even try to unlink our malware PA models
from the PEP during sleep, just before that, so that there is this no CRUD UI, no WinHTTP,
and I guess that this might even push back on some of the detection ideas coming from the
EDRs as well. We can also apply the calstack spoofers and approaches, as well as shellcode
fluctuation, which tries to leave our shellcode within the read-write or not accessible memory
pages, because we don't want to leave, we don't want to reside, and we don't want to have our
beacons left in the executable places, because as soon as the antivirus memory scanner sweeps comes
in, we don't want to be scanned, even in the first place, and the antiviruses, out of the
performance reason, are going to skip on the executable pages, because they are not... skip
